facts.text: Petitioner is an advocate practising in the courts in Dhanbad, Bihar; prominent public figure, Pramukh of Baliapur Anchal for about ten years, Vice-Chairman of Zila Parishad, Dhanbad for about four years; associated with social, educational and political institutions for uplift of down-trodden people.
16th Annual Convention of Bihar Rajya Panchayat Parishad scheduled at Gosaidih, Dhanbad on 16th March, 1974; petitioner was Chairman of Reception Committee.
Ruling party concerned about petitioner's growing popularity with backward classes; false case instituted against petitioner at P.S. Tundi to undermine his position.
Petitioner arrested at Dhanbad on 6th March, 1974; produced before Sub-Divisional Magistrate; taken to Bhagalpur Central Jail.
Petitioner applied for bail to Sub-Divisional Magistrate on 11th March, 1974; no immediate order passed.
Petitioner moved Sessions Judge for bail on 14th March, 1974; Sessions Judge granted bail.
Bail bonds verified and accepted by Sub-Divisional Magistrate; order dated 18th March, 1974 passed for release of petitioner.

District Magistrate, Dhanbad passed detention order under section 3 of Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971 on 18th March, 1974 to prevent petitioner from acting prejudicial to maintenance of public order.
Detention order in Hindi (official language) and English version; no material difference except in satisfaction recital in English version adding 'or security of the State'.
Petitioner arrested on 21st March, 1974 upon release on bail; served Hindi and English versions of detention order and grounds.

Ground 1: Petitioner propagating communal hatred between Adibasis and outsiders (Biharis) and between Adibasis and non-Adibasis for some time; instigating Adibasis to take law in own hands; public order disturbed several times; details not possible but illustrations given.

Ground 2: On 25-2-1973 at Katras Ceramic Factory, Tilatanr, P.S. Katras, petitioner instigated employees to remove outsiders (Biharis) by force; 200 armed persons attacked shop of Ram Kripal Dubey, assaulted him and father, damaged factory and quarters.

Ground 3: On 29-8-73 at Railway Football Maidan, Gomoh, P.S. Topchanchi, in speech: 'Apna Faisla Ap Karo, Pahle Gherao Karo, Fir Mukka Lath Se Maro, Fir Lathi Chhalao, Uspar Vi Nahin Sunta Hai To Sar Kat Lo.'
Ground 4: On 3-11-73 at same place, public meeting by Chotanagpur-Santbal Pargana Alag Raj Nirman Samity, instigated Adivasis and Harijans to capture lands of non-Adibasis by force and harvest paddy.
Ground 5: On 1-11-73 at Maachkocha and Mahatotund, P.S. Topchanchi, following instigation by petitioner and associates, Jhari Manjhi etc. took paddy from plots of Ram Anandi Singh.
Ground 6: On 4-2-74 at Golf Ground, Dhanbad, Jharkhand Party meeting: 'Agar Aaaz Hame Koi Hat Dikhaega To Uska Hat Kat Lange, Aur Angali Dhikaega To Angali Kat Lange.'
Ground 7: On 3-3-74 at Singhdih, P.S. Topchanchi, meeting by Jharkhand Alag Raj Nirman Samiti, instigated to capture non-Adibasi lands; 4000 armed persons in procession damaged car BRW 9981.

Ground 8: On 4-3-74 at Dumanda, P.S. Tundi, organised Manjhis (Adibasis) meeting, instigated to loot Dikus (non-Adibasis) like Joy Narayan Choudhury; on 5-3-74, 500 armed persons looted, injured Ganga Bishnu Prasad and Girdhari Rai, set fire to house.
Petitioner made representation to State Government against detention order; rejected on 24th April, 1974.
Case placed before Advisory Board; representation forwarded; petitioner heard personally; Advisory Board opined sufficient cause for detention on 2nd May, 1974.
State Government confirmed detention order on 11th May, 1974.
Petitioner filed petition under Art. 226 in Patna High Court; Division Bench rejected on 14th May, 1974.

legal_issues.text: Whether the English version of grounds using disjunctive 'or security of the State' vitiates detention order as showing non-application of mind.
Whether first ground alleging propagation of communal hatred is vague and unintelligible.
Whether District Magistrate considered more instances than those listed, as per expression in ground 1.
Whether specific grounds (e.g., ground 2, ground 4, ground 5) support communal hatred or public order disturbance.
Whether other materials in counter-affidavit of Miss Sunila Dayal were considered by District Magistrate without disclosure.

petitioner_arguments.text: English version recites satisfaction for public order 'or security of the State' showing non-serious application of mind; invalid per precedents.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Kishori Mohan Bera v. State of West Bengal; Akshoy Konai v. State of West Bengal; Section 3 MISA

petitioner_arguments.text: First ground vague: propagating communal hatred between Adibasis/outsiders (Biharis) and Adibasis/non-Adibasis.
Expression 'It would not be possible to give details of such instances' shows more instances considered without disclosure.
Ground 2 not communal hatred; ground 4/5 mere land disputes, no public order impact.
Paras 5 and 7 of Miss Sunila Dayal's affidavit show other undisclosed materials considered.

respondent_arguments.text: Counter-affidavit by Miss Sunila Dayal and District Magistrate's affidavit repel petitioner's claims of being social worker; no undisclosed materials relied upon.

court_reasoning.text: No infirmity from 'or security of State' in English grounds; Hindi authentic; satisfaction clearly for public order only; error inadvertent; each ground specifies public order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Hindi version controls; English addition incongruous mistake.

court_reasoning.text: First ground not vague: Adibasis vs outsiders (Biharis) and non-Adibasis clear; five detailed instances provided.
Expression in ground 1 means many instances but only listed ones (2-6) relied upon for satisfaction.
Ground 2 shows instigation to remove Biharis by force leading to violence: communal hatred and public order nexus; ground 4/5 part of series affecting public order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Viewed in context of series, not isolated.

court_reasoning.text: Affidavit paras repel petitioner's social worker claim; not materials for District Magistrate's satisfaction; his own affidavit confirms reliance on listed grounds.

holdings.text: Detention order valid; no infirmities found; grounds sufficient, specific to public order.
First ground not vague; instances detailed.
Specific grounds support communal hatred and public order disturbance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kishori Mohan Bera v. The State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Disjunctive 'or' in satisfaction recital invalidates if shows non-application of mind.

precedents_cited.case_name: Akshoy Konai v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Disjunctive satisfaction on public order or state security invalid.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order to prevent prejudicial acts to public order.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for writ petition in Supreme Court and High Court.

outcome.summary: Petition under Article 32 challenging detention order dismissed; all grounds rejected; no substance found; rule discharged.

key_quotes.text: "if the order of detention purports to be based on the satisfaction of the detaining authority that it is necessary to detain the petitioner with a view to preventing him from acting in a manner prejudicial to the maintenance of public order or security of the State, it would clearly be an invalid order."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains principle from precedents on disjunctive satisfaction.

key_quotes.text: "Hindi being the official language of the State, it is the Hindi version of the grounds of detention which must be regarded as authentic."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Prioritises Hindi version over erroneous English.

key_quotes.text: "These were the only grounds urged in support of the petition and since there is no substance in them, the petition fails and the rule is discharged."
key_quotes.speaker: court
